cards.back:
y(t) = x(t)*h(t) = ∫x(τ)h(t-τ)dτ

Integrate product of input x and flipped-shifted impulse response h.

x(t)

Delta is the identity element for convolution. Convolving anything with δ(t) returns the original unchanged.

x(t-T)

Convolving with shifted impulse delays signal by T. The impulse acts as a delay line.

1. Flip one signal (h(τ)→h(-τ))
2. Shift the flipped signal by t
3. Multiply overlapping portions
4. Integrate for each t

Yes! x*h = h*x

We can flip either signal in graphical convolution. Order doesn't matter.

Yes! (x*h₁)*h₂ = x*(h₁*h₂)

Can combine cascade impulse responses first, then convolve once with input.

Yes! x*(h₁+h₂) = x*h₁ + x*h₂

Represents parallel systems: analyze each path separately, then add outputs.

Duration = dur(x) + dur(h)

Durations add. A 3-second signal convolved with 2-second impulse response gives 5-second output.

cards.front: Why does convolution characterize LTI systems?
cards.back: Any input x(t) can be decomposed into scaled, shifted impulses. LTI system responds to each with scaled, shifted h(t). Convolution sums these responses.

y[n] = Σx[k]h[n-k]

Sum over k from -∞ to +∞. At each n, sum products of x[k] and shifted h[n-k].
